overview.summary: Scams surged in both number and sophistication, targeting individuals and businesses with new schemes. Cybercriminals exploited the rise of online platforms for shopping, banking, and socialising, devising clever ways to steal money.

digital_arrest_scams.description: Fraudsters impersonate law enforcement or government officials, tricking victims into paying fake fines or resolving non-existent legal issues.
digital_arrest_scams.method: Victims are contacted via phone, email, or messages, and threatened with immediate arrest if they don't comply.
digital_arrest_scams.effectiveness: Scammers use fear, urgency, fake documents, and official-looking caller IDs to make the scam convincing.

investment_scams.description: Scammers promise high returns on fake cryptocurrency projects and stock market opportunities.
investment_scams.method: Fake websites and social media profiles are used to lure victims with fabricated success stories and testimonials.
investment_scams.impact: Victims lose significant money as scammers disappear after investments are made.

other_scams.description: AI-generated videos or audio impersonate trusted individuals, tricking victims into transferring money.
Prey on job seekers by promising lucrative roles in exchange for upfront fees.
Fake QR codes redirect victims to malicious websites or steal financial data when scanned.

protection_tips: Verify authenticity through official channels before acting on calls, emails, or messages.
Be skeptical of promises of high returns with low risks.
Use strong passwords and enable two-factor authentication (2FA).
Educate yourself about common scams and share this knowledge with others.
Report suspicious activity to the cybercrime unit.

conclusion.message: The surge in scams in 2024 is a reminder of the importance of vigilance in our digital lives. Staying informed and adopting smarter digital practices can help prevent scams in 2025.
